author: By Ross Barkan
title: The D.N.C. Has a Primary Problem
description: The White House wanted South Carolina to vote first in 2024. The Democratic National Committee obliged. It hasn’t gone according to plan.
content: Last December,  the 30-odd members of the Democratic Party’s rules and bylaws committee filed in to the Omni Shoreham, the glittering resort hotel that once hosted Franklin D. Roosevelt’s inaugural ball. All of the Democrats, many of them gray-haired habitués of the rubber-chicken circuit, knew they had come to Washington to hash out, after months of debate, what the presidential-primary calendar would look like come 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Resell My Taylor Swift Concert Tickets for Thousands of Dollars?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the fairness of selling a scarce good at an exorbitant price.
content: My sister was lucky enough to get six tickets to the Taylor Swift concert in New Jersey for face value ($130) through Ticketmaster Verified Fans. She is using three of them for me, herself and my megafan daughter, and then decided recently to sell the remaining three. She looked at ticket prices online and seats in our section were being offered for around $3,000 each, plus the $900 in fees added on the last page of checkout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: The Gift of Holiday Men
description: The hole left by generations of absentee fathers is filled by a powerful matriarchy.
content: Kema Christian-Coates’s childhood was filled with “holiday men,” absentee fathers — including her own — who returned each year around Christmas only to disappear again. Her father’s absence left a hole in her life and the fear that she, like her mother and grandmother, would never find a man she could rely on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karl Russell and Jeanna Smialek
title: It’s a World of Inflation
description: Prices are still rising too fast for comfort in many major economies, and policymakers across the globe are trying to wrestle them under control.
content: From Melbourne to Manchester to Miami, people are struggling under the weight of hefty price increases for the things they buy each day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Director of New Women’s History Museum Withdraws, Citing Family Issues
description: Nancy Yao was to lead a Smithsonian museum about the influence of American women. Her withdrawal came amid a review of how she had handled sexual harassment complaints in an earlier post.
content: The Smithsonian’s choice for the founding director of its developing American Women’s History Museum has withdrawn from the role, the institution said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Officials Were Wary About Slow Inflation Progress at June Meeting
description: Federal Reserve officials are debating how high to raise interest rates to fully wrangle inflation. The debate was in focus at their meeting last month.
content: Federal Reserve officials were concerned about sluggish progress toward lower inflation and wary about the surprising staying power of the American economy at their June meeting — so much so that some even wanted to raise rates last month, instead of holding them steady as the central bank ultimately did, minutes from the gathering showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Andrew Ridgeley on George Michael and Life After Wham!
description: “The only thing I ever wanted to do from the age of 14 was to be in a band,” but he is content with the duo’s short career, which is chronicled in a new documentary.
content: If you weren’t a teenager in 1984, it might be hard to understand this, but here goes: There are Gen X-ers who remember where they were the first time they saw the video for the Wham! clap-along pop anthem “Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Social Class Is Not About Only Race
description: Class diversity has been a blind spot for many colleges. Will that now change?
content: The University of Virginia, one of the country’s top public universities, enrolls a strikingly affluent group of students: Less than 15 percent of recent undergraduates at UVA have come from families with incomes low enough to qualify for Pell Grants, the largest federal financial aid program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Thomas
title: In the Azores: Earth, Water, Fire and Air, Sometimes All at Once
description: Volcanic São Miguel, one of the nine islands in this Portuguese archipelago in the Mid-Atlantic, offers landscapes and experiences that are at once wild and serene.
content: It was 6 a.m. — 2 a.m. to my raddled East Coast brain — and my husband, daughter and I were staggering through customs in the Ponta Delgada Airport, on the island of São Miguel, the largest of the nine islands that make up Portugal’s Azores archipelago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Years After Iranian Missiles Downed a Passenger Jet, a Suit Seeks Answers
description: In 2020, Iranian missiles struck a Ukraine Airlines flight, killing all 176 people on board. Four countries have filed suit in The Hague demanding a credible account and full compensation.
content: On a clear January morning in 2020, Ukraine Airlines Flight 752 was struck by two Iranian missiles just three minutes after leaving an airport in Tehran, killing all 176 passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley, Alissa J. Rubin and Adam Goldman
title: Israeli Woman Held for Months in Iraq by Shiite Militia Linked to Iran
description: Elizabeth Tsurkov, an Israeli researcher, was seized in late March by an Iraqi Shiite group shortly after leaving a Baghdad cafe. The office of the Israeli prime minister confirmed she was being held.
content: An Israeli researcher missing for months in Iraq is being held by a Shiite militia, according to a statement from the office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Israel’s West Bank Raid Ends
description: Also, fatal floods in China and other Asian countries.
content: Israel’s military said yesterday that it had withdrawn from the occupied West Bank city of Jenin after a large-scale incursion that killed at least 12 Palestinians, left one Israeli soldier dead and sent thousands fleeing from their homes over the past two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un Wants a Satellite in Space. Seoul Says He Has a Long Way to Go.
description: After analyzing debris from the North’s recently failed rocket launch, South Korea concluded that the isolated country’s satellite technology was useless.
content: The satellite that North Korea attempted to put into orbit in May was so rudimentary that it could never serve as a functioning spy satellite as North Korea wished, the South Korean military said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Michael Crowley
title: Biden Says He Is ‘Anxiously’ Waiting for Sweden to Join NATO
description: In an Oval Office meeting, President Biden again backed the plan for Sweden to join the military alliance, but movement has been stalled by Turkey’s opposition.
content: President Biden told Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson of Sweden on Wednesday that he was “anxiously looking forward” to the country’s acceptance into NATO, reiterating their shared goal of strengthening the Western alliance against the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: P.S.G. Says Mbappé Must Sign a New Deal or Leave the Club
description: Nasser al-Khelaifi, the president of Paris St.-Germain, was introducing the team’s new coach when he turned to tough talk on the future of his team’s biggest star.
content: It was at the unveiling of yet another new coach that Paris St.-Germain’s president made his first public statement on the future of his team’s best player. He did not equivocate and left little room for compromise.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 5, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 5, 2023.
content: An article on Monday about people accused of being Russian spies in Albania referred incorrectly to the photographer Svetlana Timofeyeva’s job. Her main source of income came from working as a tour guide, not making videos and taking photographs for weddings and corporate events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: GQ Removes Article Critical of Warner Bros. Discovery C.E.O.
description: The magazine took down the story on David Zaslav without any explanation, an unusual move for a publication.
content: The article on the GQ website was a fierce critique of David Zaslav, comparing the Warner Bros. Discovery chief executive to the ruthless business tycoon played by Richard Gere in “Pretty Woman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pomerantz
title: Guess Who’s Been Paying to Block Green Energy. You Have.
description: As regulated monopolies, utilities have the unique ability to force customers to fund their political activities through monthly bills.
content: To avoid the worst impacts of climate change, we have to make two big transitions at once: First, we have to generate all of our electricity from clean sources, like wind turbines and solar panels, rather than power plants that run on coal and methane gas. Second, we have to retool nearly everything else that burns oil and gas — like cars, buses and furnaces that heat buildings — to run on that clean electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Yusef Salaam Is Declared Winner of Harlem City Council Primary Race
description: Mr. Salaam was one of the Central Park Five who were wrongly convicted and then exonerated in the rape and assault of a jogger in Central Park in 1989.
content: Yusef Salaam, one of five Black and Latino men whose convictions were overturned in the 1989 rape and assault of a female jogger in Central Park, cemented his victory in a highly contested City Council primary race in Harlem, according to The Associated Press on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Olivia Wang
title: A Drone and a Crane Save the Day as China Reels From Extreme Weather
description: Heavy rains and heat waves have affected parts of China and the Asia Pacific region this week. More of the same was in the forecast.
content: China and several other Asia Pacific countries were reeling from monsoonal floods and stultifying temperatures on Wednesday, the latest disruptions in what forecasters say could be a long summer and autumn of extreme weather around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
title: Disinformation Researchers Fret About Fallout From Judge’s Order
description: They said a restriction on government interaction with social media companies could impede efforts to curb false claims about vaccines and voter fraud.
content: A federal judge’s decision this week to restrict the government’s communication with social media platforms could have broad side effects, according to researchers and groups that combat hate speech, online abuse and disinformation: It could further hamper efforts to curb harmful content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Israel’s Deadly Operation in the West Bank, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Mass Shooting in Philadelphia: What to Know
description: An assailant dressed in a ski mask and body armor killed five people and injured two others, the authorities said, in what officials are treating as a random attack.
content: An attacker using a military-style rifle killed five people and injured two children during a shooting spree in a Philadelphia neighborhood on Monday, firing shots on the open street and bringing terror to passers-by before being caught by the police. Officials said they are treating the shooting as a random attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Rabbi’s Brush With Danger in Ukraine Went Viral
description: A video put a fresh spotlight on the chief rabbi of Ukraine, whose renown predates his humanitarian efforts since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — It was a striking image: a bearded rabbi with a flak jacket over his tallit, hitting the ground to take cover as shells boomed around him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Review Faults Oversight of Classified Information
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin ordered the assessment after accusations that an Air National Guardsman disclosed sensitive information.
content: The Pentagon’s security and oversight measures have failed to keep pace with the proliferation of military facilities that handle classified information and the personnel who work there, but the Defense Department does not have a systemic problem in keeping its secrets secret, a new review made public on Wednesday concludes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Who Knew the Colosseum Was So Old? Tourist Apologizes for Defacement.
description: A man who etched his initials and those of his girlfriend in a wall of the nearly 2,000-year-old monument wrote a letter of apology, and his lawyer says he is hoping for a plea bargain.
content: A man seen on video last month using his keys to etch his love for his girlfriend on a wall in the Colosseum in Rome has written a letter of apology, saying he had no idea the nearly 2,000-year-old monument was so ancient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China Took Her Husband. She Was Left to Uncover His Secret Cause.
description: He was brilliant, quirky and intensely private — and also, she now suspects, an anonymous dissident blogger who had won fame for years of evading the surveillance state.
content: It wasn’t as if Bei Zhenying didn’t know that her husband was unusual, or even that he had some secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Women’s Bracket Showcases a Potential Big Three in the Making
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 5, 2023.
content: “I felt so bad, and I just couldn’t watch it. Every time if Wimbledon would be on TV, I would cry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: As Businesses Clamor for Workplace A.I., Tech Companies Rush to Provide It
description: Amazon, Box, Salesforce, Oracle and others have recently rolled out A.I.-related products to help workplaces become more efficient and productive.
content: Earlier this year, Mark Austin, the vice president of data science at AT&T, noticed that some of the company’s developers had started using the ChatGPT chatbot at work. When the developers got stuck, they asked ChatGPT to explain, fix or hone their code.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Man Who Wants to Be the Biggest Thing in Fashion
description: Guram Gvasalia of Vetements revealed that he had been making the costumes for Madonna’s postponed tour right in the middle of couture week. It was a classic move.
content: Of all the many Madonna-related posts that have appeared on social media since it was revealed that the artist had been taken ill and forced to postpone her “Celebration” tour, one in particular stood out — not just because of what it said, but because of what it showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Hiba Yazbek
title: West Bank Teenagers Are Writing Out Their Last Words
description: In one of the deadliest periods in years in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, young Palestinians drawn into the struggle against Israel are writing farewell messages to their loved ones.
content: Before Amr Khamour, 14, was killed, shot twice by Israeli troops as he hurled stones at a military jeep in his hometown, he spent his time dancing with friends, recording TikTok videos on his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: In the Age of A.I., Tech’s Little Guys Need Big Friends
description: Creating a new A.I. system requires lots of money and lots of computing power, which is controlled by the industry’s giants.
content: The tech industry loves its garage start-up stories. From Hewlett-Packard to Google, the tales of bootstrapped companies that have turned into giants has inspired generations of entrepreneurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff
title: In Business, ‘Flat’ Structures Rarely Work. Is There a Solution?
description: Companies that have rejected hierarchies have typically lacked diversity and, in at least one case, faced scandal. A new crop of them is aiming to find a middle ground.
content: Elizabeth Claypoole was taking her dog to day care when she bumped into Eric Ward, one of the chief executives at Ag Biome, a North Carolina biotechnology company where she is head of human resources. When the day-care receptionist asked how they knew each other, she said, “Well, he’s kind of my boss.” Mr. Ward cringed. Ag Biome operates with a “flat” business model: It eschews managers, favoring committees instead. Despite their titles, the co-founders, Scott Uknes and Mr. Ward, are, Ms. Claypoole said, “anti-C.E.O.s.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Ukraine Strikes a Russian-Occupied City, Igniting a Huge Blast
description: Ukrainian and Russian officials differed on whether a military or civilian area had been struck. Earlier in the war, Russia lost dozens of soldiers, if not hundreds, in a strike on the city.
content: Ukraine’s military launched an overnight strike on the Russian-occupied city of Makiivka, showing that it could still attack targets deep behind Russian lines as its troops fight in grueling trench warfare in a counteroffensive to reclaim land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: 250 Pounds of Pot, a Taco Truck and a Cross-Country Road Trip
description: Scott Von Doviak’s novel “Lowdown Road” evokes “The Dukes of Hazzard” — in a good way.
content: Scott Von Doviak has done the unthinkable: made me take the television show “The Dukes of Hazzard” more seriously. His latest novel, LOWDOWN ROAD (Hard Case Crime, 287 pp., paperback, $15.95) — with its hapless good ol’ boy antiheroes clad in aviator sunglasses, crotch-hugging Levis and Lynyrd Skynyrd T-shirts — clearly takes inspiration from the series.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transgender Athletes in Women’s Sports
description: Readers respond to a column by David French. Also: Banning nuclear weapons; premature book reviews; walking in the city.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: This Melon Salad Is Pure Pleasure
description: Flavor and texture take top billing in a simple Jamaican dish.
content: When I cook for myself, the only real guideline I follow is the pursuit of flavor — everything else is a suggestion. And sometimes, particularly with a cuisine I’m not too familiar with, this means following a recipe to the letter. But more often than not, pleasure is the goal, which means steamed cabbage and carrots sprinkled with shichimi togarashi; or Red Stripe-marinated chicken, battered in potato starch, fried and slathered with miso mayo; or, among friends, a whole fried snapper served alongside basil, fried shallots, sa tế and lettuce, for wrapping. Usually, it’s in this quest for flavor that I realize what’s actually most comforting for me in a given moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juli Fraga
title: How to Deal With Financial Trauma
description: Experiences like economic hardship or medical expenses can distort people’s feelings and behaviors around money, causing them to sabotage their financial futures.
content: Rahkim Sabree owns a home in Hartford, Conn., invests and has money in savings. But that isn’t always enough to make him feel secure. Unexpected expenses, regardless of the cost, bring him discomfort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Medicare Advantage Plans Offer Few Psychiatrists
description: A new study finds that people have a very difficult time finding doctors in their networks under the private-sector policies.
content: People with private Medicare coverage may not be getting the mental health services they need because they cannot find a psychiatrist within their plan’s network, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: At 20, an Upstate Arts Haven Keeps Breaking New Ground
description: The Fisher Center at Bard has become an incubator for commercially promising new work like Justin Peck’s “Illinois,” while holding tight to its experimental roots.
content: On a recent Saturday night, a group of young people were gathered in this bucolic hamlet in the Hudson Valley, building a campfire of sorts. There were no matches or flames, but there were lanterns, chirping crickets, fir trees swirled with haze and, at one point, a zombie attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: subsequent
description: This word has appeared in 883 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word subsequent has appeared in 883 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 7 in “‘No Next Steps’ as of Yet for Aaron Judge’s Toe Injury” by Tyler Kepner:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
title: ‘Dig, Dig, Dig’: A Russian Soldier’s Story
description: An inmate hoped to start over with a clean slate by fighting in Ukraine. Instead, he was confronted by the drudgery of trench work and the terror of battle. “You’re going in as meat,” he said he was told.
content: The Russian soldier was captured only days after arriving on the front line in eastern Ukraine. He had little training. But he knew how to disassemble and fire his rifle and where to put a tourniquet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: How to Talk About Marital Unhappiness Before It’s Too Late
description: Former Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City and his wife, Chirlane McCray, announced they were separating after growing apart. Here’s what experts advise if you’re wondering about your own relationship.
content: Former Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City and his wife, Chirlane McCray, announced that they were separating after nearly 30 years in an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday. Their story begins with an “aha” moment in the midst of what the article calls yet another “stale Saturday night of binge-watching television” together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Threads, Instagram’s ‘Twitter Killer,’ Has Arrived
description: Here’s what to know about Instagram’s new app for public conversations and how it differs from Twitter.
content: After months of speculation and secrecy, Mark Zuckerberg’s long-rumored competitor app to Twitter is here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Had an Affair With Someone My Spouse and I See Socially. Help!
description: After ending a yearslong extramarital affair, a reader worries about a coming dinner party that will be attended by both the former lover and the reader’s spouse.
content: I had an extramarital affair for several years. It ended recently — abruptly and unpleasantly — and I blocked all digital and telephonic communication with my ex to ensure that I don’t weaken and get involved again. The affair was fulfilling sexually and emotionally, but it was also taboo: We are both otherwise happily married and socialize together as couples. Now, I am apprehensive about future encounters. Recently, we all juggled our calendars to attend a small, upcoming dinner party at a third couple’s home. How should I handle this? I don’t want to reach out and ask for a truce; my emotions are still too raw — with hurt and anger not far from the surface. I don’t know how to justify canceling the dinner to my spouse, but I’m afraid I may lose it if I go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: America Is Living on Borrowed Money
description: The nation needs to chart a new course on federal debt.
content: The federal debt is as old as the nation, and adding to it is sometimes prudent. For governments confronting existential crises like wars or pandemics, borrowing makes sense as a way to mobilize national resources, as the economist Barry Eichengreen wrote in the 2021 book “In Defense of Public Debt.” Government borrowing and spending are necessary to stimulate the economy during recessions. And Treasuries, safe and liquid, play a critical role in the global financial system — so much so that in the late 1990s, when a period of economic growth and reduced military spending allowed the government to sharply reduce borrowing, economists and bankers raised alarms about the consequences of too little federal debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kin Woo
title: An Artist Whose Language Is Painting
description: Christina Quarles discusses representation, trades and protein shakes.
content: Growing up in Los Angeles as the fair-skinned daughter of a Black father and a white mother, Christina Quarles, 38, can recall the first time her sense of identity was challenged: “In elementary school, there was this book of famous Black people throughout history and my nana was in there,” she said. (Her paternal grandmother, Norma Quarles, was one of the first Black TV journalists.) “I would show the other kids that was my grandmother in the book but get told, ‘No, you’re not Black.’ It was this disconnect between how I was raised with my own personal sense of my biography, and then to be met with such resistance when I would express that to people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: A Corn Pudding That Tastes Like Elotes
description: “It’s like Mexican street corn and cornbread had a baby.”
content: Hi. It’s me, Kim Severson! It’s that time of the summer when everyone but me goes on vacation. This means I get to talk about something my friends and family are tired of hearing, which is how much reporting power fuels everything we do over here in the best section of The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.5 Million Homes in Colorado, Washington and Maine
description: A midcentury-modern showplace in Denver, a renovated hillside home in Seattle and an 1812 Federal house on the coast in Kittery Point.
content: This house, designed by Richard W. Quinn, a past president of the American Institute of Architects’ Connecticut chapter, is on the market for the first time since it was built in 1966. It is half a block from the popular oversized sundial at Cranmer Park and less than a mile from public elementary and middle schools. A movie theater and a Trader Joe’s are also nearby, on Colorado Boulevard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: This Bulgarian Writer’s Books Bend Time
description: Georgi Gospodinov won the prestigious International Booker Prize this year for “Time Shelter,” a satirical novel exploring lofty ideas about nostalgia.
content: When the Bulgarian author Georgi Gospodinov was writing the novel “Time Shelter,” in 2019, he agonized over a scene he thought might be over the top, even for a work of absurdist fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Adeel Hassan
title: Deadly Louisiana Shooting Caps a Holiday Weekend of Violence
description: The shooting, which left four dead and seven wounded, was one of several in multiple cities since Friday.
content: As the long Fourth of July weekend drew to a close, a final spasm of gun violence close to midnight left four people dead and seven others wounded at an outdoor party in Shreveport, La., following earlier shootings in Philadelphia, Baltimore, Fort Worth and other cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: When Did the U.S. Become a Democracy?
description: Until fairly recently, that would have seemed like a peculiar question. But many experts on American history and political science say U.S. democracy is relatively young.
content: How old were you when the United States became a democracy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Campaign Continues to Struggle to Find Its Footing
description: The Florida governor, who has yet to demonstrate himself as a campaigner on a national stage, has been plagued by a series of unforced errors and has yet to make a strong case against Donald Trump.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, looking to shift his run for president into a higher gear after an early series of missteps, spent the last two weeks rolling out an immigration policy and holding town halls with voters. But rather than correcting course, he stumbled again this week, raising questions about where his campaign is heading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Bill de Blasio and Chirlane McCray Are Separating
description: Mr. de Blasio’s marriage helped fuel his campaign for mayor of New York, and his intense personal and political bond with his wife drew admiration and scrutiny.
content: About two months ago, after another stale Saturday night of binge-watching television at their Brooklyn home, Bill de Blasio and Chirlane McCray surprised themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In a Ukrainian Hospital, Interviewing a Wounded Russian Soldier
description: Two video journalists for The New York Times were reporting on the lives of Ukrainian combat medics when an injured Russian soldier arrived at the hospital.
content: It wasn’t the first time we had met a Russian soldier in Ukraine. During the course of our eight-month investigation into potential war crimes committed by Russian forces in Bucha last year, we spoke to two Russian paratroopers in Ukrainian custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: In ‘The Horror of Dolores Roach,’ the Empanadas Are to Die For
description: Justina Machado and Aaron Mark went uptown to sample the savory pastries that play a central role in their new horror-comedy — minus the mystery meat.
content: You know those days when you would kill for an empanada? Well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Face Conspiracy Theories in Jan. 6 Trial
description: A man charged with plotting to storm the Capitol is the latest to use baseless assertions as a defense, leading prosecutors to warn of “a circuslike atmosphere.”
content: Almost from the moment that a pro-Trump mob stormed into the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, conspiracy theories have ricocheted from the fringes of the internet to the corridors of Congress. Republican officials and others on the right have dismissed the attack as the work of mere tourists, or sought to depict it as a false-flag operation by shadowy leftist groups — or even the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel Says Deadly Raid on West Bank City Is Over
description: A major military incursion into the city of Jenin left at least 12 Palestinians and one Israeli soldier dead. A Palestinian attack on Tel Aviv wounded at least eight.
content: Israel’s military said on Wednesday that it had withdrawn from the occupied West Bank city of Jenin after a large-scale incursion that killed at least 12 Palestinians, left one Israeli soldier dead and sent thousands fleeing from their homes over the past two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo and Judson Jones
title: Holiday Fireworks Worsen Air Quality Nationwide
description: Seattle, New York City and Los Angeles were among the places with high air quality indexes after fireworks celebrations.
content: The air quality index Wednesday morning reached the “unhealthy” benchmark in cities across the United States including Seattle, Los Angeles and Pittsburgh. Millions of Americans have felt the effects of thick smoke from Canadian wildfires in recent weeks, but experts said the smog this time was likely to be a combination of Fourth of July fireworks, stagnant air and, in some areas, West Coast wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A New Ruling Could Complicate Biden’s Policy on Social Media
description: A judge’s decision to limit how the administration can interact with platforms could chill the White House’s efforts to utilize and police big tech.
content: Government efforts to interact with social media platforms took a major hit on Tuesday when a federal judge restricted the Biden administration from communicating with tech companies about a broad array of online content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Secret Service Investigating Who Brought Cocaine Into the White House
description: A baggie that was confirmed to contain cocaine was found in the guest lobby of the West Wing on Sunday evening, an agency spokesman said.
content: The Secret Service is looking to find out who brought a baggie of cocaine that was discovered on Sunday evening into a guest lobby of the West Wing of the White House, an agency spokesman said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Meet Blackbraid, a Black Metal Musician With Native American Roots
description: Sgah’gahsowáh, the artist behind the one-man band, combines the genre’s traditional heavy sounds with a focus on nature. His new album, “Blackbraid II,” is out Friday.
content: Black metal has long been associated with the gray skies, snowy landscapes and Norse mythology of Scandinavia. Most people know it, if at all, as the musical genre associated with church burnings and gory homicides in early 1990s Norway. (Those events were documented in the book “Lords of Chaos,” which was adapted into a 2019 feature starring Rory Culkin as the misanthropic, occultist musician Euronymous.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Wolfram and Campbell Robertson
title: Suspect Showed Troubling Signs Before Philadelphia Rampage, D.A. Says
description: People who lived with the suspect told investigators that he was wearing a bulletproof vest around the house in the days before five people were gunned down.
content: As the streets outside his home echoed with pops, Darryl Steplight thought it was fireworks on the eve of the Fourth of July. He quickly learned otherwise. A man in body armor, and carrying an AR-15-style rifle, had opened fire at random in the neighborhood, killing five and wounding two, including a 2-year-old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold, Nina Feldman, Will Reid, Carlos Prieto, Rachelle Bonja, Marc Georges, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How MrBeast Became the Willy Wonka of YouTube
description: The social media megastar regularly goes viral for giving away money in extremely extravagant and colorful ways.
content: Jimmy Donaldson, better known as MrBeast, has become a sensation on YouTube for ostentatious and sometimes absurd acts of altruism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Three Vaccines for Fall: What You Need to Know
description: Here’s who should get the flu, Covid and R.S.V. vaccines, and when.
content: Most Americans have had one or more shots of the flu and Covid vaccines. New this year are the first shots to protect older adults from respiratory syncytial virus, a lesser-known threat whose toll in hospitalizations and deaths may rival that of flu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Winchester
title: In Too Deep
description: Laura Trethewey’s “The Deepest Map” explores the new world of oceanic exploration — and its dangers.
content: In the past days, the world has been riveted by the story of the Titan submersible, which we now know imploded some 1,600 feet from the wreckage of the Titanic, killing all aboard. Beyond the human tragedy — and the macabre fact that James Cameron’s blockbuster is trending online — comes an opportunity for serious reflection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Paralyzed by a Police Bullet, He Describes a Life Forever Changed
description: “Why did you run from me?” an officer asked Khalif Cooper, then 28, immediately after the shooting in Paterson, N.J. “I was scared,” he answered.
content: The bullet, fired by a police officer who was sprinting into the 3 a.m. darkness, struck Khalif Cooper with improbable precision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Five Minutes That Will Make You Love Avant-Garde Jazz
description: This challenging subgenre, including the subset of free jazz, is driven by the fire of spontaneity, and its rules are still being written. Eleven writers, critics and musicians share their favorites.
content: Lately The New York Times has asked jazz musicians, writers and scholars to share the favorites that would make a friend fall in love with Herbie Hancock, New Orleans jazz, Sun Ra or Mary Lou Williams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Backed NATO Expansion, but It Won’t Be Easy
description: Also, a flurry of gun violence. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson of Sweden at the White House today to emphasize America’s support for the Nordic nation’s swift acceptance into NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Katie Rogers
title: Biden and the Swedish prime minister meet to discuss Sweden’s NATO bid.
description: President Biden and the prime minister of Sweden met at the White House on Wednesday, during a week of diplomacy by the two leaders to persuade opponents to allow the Nordic nation to join NATO.
content: President Biden and the prime minister of Sweden met at the White House on Wednesday, during a week of diplomacy by the two leaders to persuade opponents to allow the Nordic nation to join NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘Wham!’ Review: They Made It Big, Then Broke Up
description: A new movie documents George Michael and Andrew Ridgeley’s storming of the pop airwaves as the duo Wham! and laughs past the thorny questions.
content: The new documentary about George Michael, Andrew Ridgeley and the music they made as Wham! — it’s just called “Wham!” — found me in a moment of need for a nostalgic, fantastical elixir, something short, sweet and tangential to my feeling of national blues. For one thing, Wham!, the duo, made soul music that popped. And the movie dances past all of the thorny moral and ethical questions of white people making Black stuff. Those questions don’t exist at all in this movie. That’s the fantasy. And I’m here for it. But also: Wham! didn’t have any thorns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘Until Tomorrow, Wordle!’: The Week 2 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: Jack Cole, 16, reflects on his 648 days of playing the popular New York Times game.
content: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the second of 10, we received 753 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Jack Cole, as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At Wimbledon, Everyone’s Chasing Swiatek, Sabalenka and Rybakina
description: Expect the three top-ranked women to dominate the tournament. But at least one, the defending champion Elena Rybakina, says she isn’t taking any opponent for granted.
content: LONDON — Elena Rybakina was nervous. She was embroiled in her first match on Wimbledon’s Centre Court as defending champion. She was facing a tough opponent in Shelby Rogers. The roof was closed and she was recovering from a virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Yasmin Marikar
title: Christina Najjar’s Napa Valley
description: The influencer known as Tinx offers a list full of the “rich mom” energy she’s known for, but her choices won’t all break the bank.
content: The author and influencer Christina Najjar — known to her more than two million social media followers as Tinx — spent eight formative years in the Bay Area of Northern California, attending Stanford University, where she majored in English, and working in San Francisco for the Gap, Poshmark and other companies. During her time in the region, she frequently decamped to wine country seeking revelry and respite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: The Ukraine War Changed This Company Forever
description: Nokian Tyres of Finland made 80 percent of its tires in Russia, where energy was cheap. After losing billions, it prioritized political security over business efficiency.
content: Even with sheets of rain falling, the sprawling construction site was buzzing. Yellow and orange excavators slowly danced around a maze of muddy pits, swinging giant fistfuls of dirt as a chorus line of trucks traipsed across the landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Michelle Wie West Wants One More Crack at a Major
description: Wie West, one of the savviest stars women’s golf has ever had, intends to step away after the U.S. Women’s Open at Pebble Beach. She could be done as soon as Friday.
content: You could see the head tilts and darting glances when people peered around Pebble Beach's Gallery Cafe, or as visitors sat on the patio that looks toward the cypress-guarded 18th green by Stillwater Cove. They surfaced at a luncheon with Brandi Chastain and Kristi Yamaguchi, and during a climb up a flight of stairs, and a stroll through a lobby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Federal Officials Hatch a Three-Pronged Defense Against Another ‘Tripledemic’
description: This fall, Americans will be urged to get shots against the flu, Covid and, if they’re older, R.S.V.
content: To prevent a repeat of last winter’s “tripledemic” of respiratory illnesses, Americans will be encouraged to roll up their sleeves not just for flu shots but for two other vaccines, one of them entirely new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Sarah Benson Thinks Audiences Want a Challenge
description: At the helm of Soho Rep, Benson presided over a long streak of ambitious, thought-provoking works. As she heads out the door, she reflects on her vision for theater’s future and plans for her own.
content: Contemporary American theater would not be the same without a 65-seat theater tucked away on a quiet TriBeCa side street. Founded in 1975, Soho Rep has produced new, often boundary-pushing plays, including, in recent years, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s “An Octoroon,” in 2014, and Jackie Sibblies Drury’s Pulitzer Prize-winning “Fairview,” in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: ‘That. Is. Nuts.’
description: Joe Deeney broadens our horizons.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: New Car Sales Jumped in the Second Quarter
description: General Motors, Toyota and other automakers sold more trucks and sport utility vehicles as supply chain problems eased and demand remained strong despite rising interest rates.
content: Some of the country’s biggest automakers reported big sales increases for the second quarter on Wednesday, the strongest sign yet that the auto industry was bouncing back from parts shortages and overcoming the effects of higher interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: For Yusef Salaam, a Landslide Just Might Be the Best Revenge
description: After his wrongful conviction as one of the Central Park Five was overturned, Mr. Salaam found it hard to rebuild his life. Now he stands to take office next year.
content: This week, 34 years after he and four other teenage boys who barely knew one another were bound together by notorious failures of justice, Yusef Salaam was officially declared the winner in the Democratic primary for a seat in New York’s City Council, having received almost 64 percent of the vote. Given that more than three-quarters of voters in the district identify as Democrats, we can assume that beginning in January, he will represent Harlem, where he grew up, was arrested and returned after serving nearly seven years in prison for a crime he did not commit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Major Incursion in the West Bank Is Over. Did It Solve Anything?
description: Israelis and Palestinians said the armed groups that were the targets of the military raid would quickly rebuild and the Israeli soldiers would be back soon.
content: Before 8 a.m. on Wednesday, the Israeli military said it had finished its incursion into the West Bank city of Jenin, aimed at curbing attacks on Israelis by armed Palestinians. Barely five hours later, about 25 miles away, shots fired from a car with Palestinian plates hit an Israeli police vehicle, causing damage but no casualties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German Government Slashes Spending, Except on the Military
description: The proposed package foresees spending about 6 percent less in 2024 from this year, in a return to financial austerity. But the severity of the cuts to social services drew sharp criticism.
content: Germany plans to slash social benefits and rein in government debt but increase the amount spent on the military in 2024, according to a federal budget approved Wednesday by the government of Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: How Shun Lee (the Other One) Turned Into Dim Sum Bloom
description: When an outpost of the beloved Chinese restaurant Shun Lee opened on West 98th Street, it created a lot of drama. Now it’s rebranding.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we are bringing you an important update on a tempest in a green tea teapot, involving an Upper West Side Chinese restaurant that dared to call itself “Shun Lee.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Commercial-Scale Wind Farm Off New Jersey Coast Approved
description: The project in the waters southeast of Atlantic City marks the third major wind farm authorized by the Biden administration.
content: The U.S. Bureau of Ocean Energy Management on Wednesday approved the construction of up to 98 wind turbine generators off the coast of Atlantic City, N.J., as part of a Biden administration plan to install offshore wind sites along the country’s coasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: An outburst of tit-for-tat violence in Israel and the West Bank.
content: Hours after Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said last night that a military incursion aimed at Palestinian armed groups in the West Bank city of Jenin was wrapping up, five rockets were fired from the Gaza Strip into Israel, raising fears of more violence. No injuries were reported, and the Israeli military said the country’s air defense system had intercepted all five rockets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Olivia Rodrigo Returns, Fall Out Boy Denies History
description: Plus: “Barbie” memes and the Grimace Shake attacks.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: California Man Hid Mother’s Death for 3 Decades to Collect Her Benefits
description: Donald Felix Zampach, 65, received more than $830,000 in payments from the government intended for his late mother. He also took possession of her home while it was still in her name.
content: A California man has admitted that he hid his mother’s death from the federal government for over three decades so that he could collect more than $800,000 in benefits intended for her, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Hanover Township, N.J.: ‘A Nice, Family-Oriented Place’
description: With good schools and relatively low property taxes, this Morris County community is popular with buyers. No surprise, then, that the market is tight.
content: Tired of the scorching weather and the constant threat of wildfires, Andrew and Carolyn Trexler decided early this year that it was time to abandon their five-year experiment of living in Northern California. So they left to return to their home turf of North Jersey. The only problem was securing a house in a highly competitive market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Extreme Weather Could Threaten California’s Dams
description: A conversation with Christopher Cox, who wrote about the near-failure of the Oroville Dam and whether it could happen again.
content: Perhaps you’ve heard that climate change in California is exacerbating what’s sometimes called “weather whiplash”: Dry periods are stretching longer, interrupted by storms that are growing bigger and more furious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: A Tech Checklist for the Dark Side of Summer Weather
description: This season has seen excessive heat, violent storms and hazardous smoke already, but you can prepare for future events with a few apps and tools.
content: Summer is in full swing now, but along with vacation trips, camp and lazy days, extreme weather has arrived for many parts of the country. If you live in an area that’s prone to such conditions, it helps to be ready. Here are some tips to help you use your tech through major meteorological moments — sometimes, even when power and cell service are shaky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Where the Republican Candidates Stand on Ukraine
description: The war has illuminated one of the biggest ideological divides within the Republican Party: between members who see a significant global role for the United States, and a more isolationist wing.
content: Few issues have been more divisive among the Republican presidential candidates than the war in Ukraine and how, if at all, the United States should be involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter, Blake Gopnik, Max Lakin and Travis Diehl
title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in July
description: Want to see new art in the city? Check out Edgar Calel’s solo show, Phase 2’s symbology and Denzil Hurley’s “made-found abstraction.” And don’t miss Cosima von Bonin’s “Church of Daffy.”
content: In important ways the New York contemporary art world was a much bigger place three decades ago than it is today, not in size but in its thinking. For a few multiculturalist years our smaller, adventurous art spaces experimented with bringing spirituality into their premises, not just as an object of study but as an active practice, a way to think about what art is, or can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Coco Lee, ‘Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon’ and ‘Mulan’ Singer, Dies at 48
description: A pop star across Asia by her early 20s, Ms. Lee reached international recognition with an Oscar-nominated song in 2001.
content: Coco Lee, a Chinese American singer and songwriter best known for performing an Oscar-nominated song in the film “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” died on Wednesday. She was 48.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Pro-Vaccine Views Are Winning. Don’t Fear the Skeptics.
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is getting a lot of play, but his views are in the minority.
content: With Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, vaccine skepticism has been back in the headlines. Though Kennedy has said he isn’t anti-vaccine and that his children have had vaccines, and his campaign manager (the former Democratic congressman and presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich) says calling Kennedy “anti-vax” is a “left-handed smear,” Kennedy continues to suggest a link between vaccines and autism — a link that has leaned heavily on flawed and retracted science. He’s also been a vocal opponent of Covid vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: Easy Mode: Clues for Friday, July 7, 2023
description: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
content: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Supreme Court Didn’t Put Racism on a Leash. It Granted It License.
description: By striking down affirmative action, justices take the absurd position that racism must be ignored for racism to be overcome.
content: There is a recurrent theme in American history: the clawing back of hard-won progress. And the Supreme Court last week used the most specious of arguments to do so with affirmative action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Coulehan and Edgar Sandoval
title: El Paso Gunman Is Confronted by Victims’ Families at Sentencing
description: The attacker faces sentencing after pleading guilty to federal hate crimes charges. “Why is it us in pain and not you?” asked one survivor of the rampage that killed 23.
content: Emotional testimony from survivors and victims’ families began on Wednesday in the federal sentencing hearing for the gunman who killed 23 people and injured dozens more at a Walmart store in El Paso, one of the deadliest attacks targeting Latinos in modern U.S. history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sauerbrey
title: Germany Is Learning a Hard Lesson
description: As the country ventures beyond the West, it is revisiting its sense of self.
content: BERLIN — It’s not often that the publication of a policy paper is cause for excitement. But when the German government set out the country’s first national security strategy in June, it set off a flurry of coverage. The document, in the end, was a bit of a disappointment. Partly that was because, for all its focus on pressing matters of foreign policy, it seemed to miss something significant: a clear change in the country’s orientation. For the first time in the postwar period, Germany is paying proper attention to the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: For Some Key Voters, Trump Has Become Toxic
description: But we are still in the dark about 2024.
content: One of the most significant developments in the run-up to the 2024 presidential election has emerged largely under the radar. From 2016 to 2022, the number of white people without college degrees — the core of Donald Trump’s support — has fallen by 2.1 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Man Gets Life Sentence in Rape of Child Who Traveled for Abortion
description: Gerson Fuentes agreed to a plea deal after he was charged with raping a 9-year-old Ohio girl who later traveled to Indiana for an abortion.
content: Last year, the story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio who had traveled to Indiana for an abortion became a flashpoint in the nationwide abortion debate. On Wednesday, the Ohio man who had been charged with raping the girl pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life in prison with the possibility of parole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: How to Squeeze a Feminist Farce Into an English Country House
description: “The Cottage” is a throwback play with a modern mind-set. The cast, playwright and director talk about pulling off the comedy and landing all the “darlings.”
content: The new Broadway comedy “The Cottage” begins with a pair of lovers in an English country house in 1923, the morning after their annual illicit tryst. Sylvia, played by the “Legally Blonde” star Laura Bell Bundy, is aflame with passion for her paramour, Beau, played by Eric McCormack of “Will & Grace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: ‘Smallville’ Actress Who Recruited Women for Nxivm Is Released From Prison
description: Allison Mack, the former “Smallville” actress, was sentenced to three years in prison in 2021.
content: Allison Mack, the “Smallville” actress who recruited women to the cultlike group Nxivm and assisted prosecutors in convicting its leader of sex trafficking and other crimes, was released from a federal prison this week after serving two years of a three-year sentence on racketeering and racketeering conspiracy charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Formal Landscaping With Native Plants? Yes, It’s Possible.
description: If you can create a native garden that looks at home on the grounds of a historic Philadelphia Main Line estate, you can do it anywhere.
content: The task facing anyone designing a garden: “We’re predicting the future — we’re seeing what’s not there.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: With the Stone of Destiny and Mary’s Crown, Scotland Names Charles King
description: While this one was purely ceremonial, it offered the king a chance to mend fences with a nation that is not hugely enamored of him or the monarchy.
content: For most royals, one coronation would be enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roland Fryer
title: Why Yale and Harvard Should Start Funding High Schools
description: The best way to find bright disadvantaged minority candidates is to help create them.
content: The best way to find bright disadvantaged minority candidates is to help create them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Fix College Admissions Now
description: With the Supreme Court’s recent ruling on affirmative action, the world of higher education is poised for a transformation.
content: With the Supreme Court’s recent ruling on affirmative action, the world of higher education is poised for a transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Harvard, Howard and Middle Tennessee State: 7 Students on 7 Campuses
description: This is a portrait of college life in America before the fall of affirmative action.
content: This is a portrait of college life in America before the fall of affirmative action.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Early Prime Day Deals of 2023
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darrick Hamilton and Demond Drummer
title: The Best Affirmative Action Workaround Is to Invest in H.B.C.U.s
description: Black institutions can offer more justice through education than diversity ever could.
content: Black institutions can offer more justice through education than diversity ever could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olufemi Ogundele
title: What Colleges Across America Can Learn From U.C. Berkeley
description: How we’ve fought to maintain diversity on campus — without affirmative action.
content: How we’ve fought to maintain diversity on campus — without affirmative action.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Elemental’ Review: In Pixar’s New Movie, Sparks Fly
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard D. Kahlenberg
title: Affirmative Action Still Exists — for the Rich
description: Admissions should focus on class, not race, to help the disadvantaged.
content: Admissions should focus on class, not race, to help the disadvantaged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Diplomat’ and More
description: I’m a health and science reporter for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I’m a health and science reporter for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sweet Cold Foam Recipe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Warikoo
title: College Admissions Have Never Been a Meritocracy
description: Now that affirmative action is gone, it’s time to rethink the ideal campus.
content: Now that affirmative action is gone, it’s time to rethink the ideal campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tomiko Brown-Nagin
title: A Diverse Campus Is Still Worth Fighting For. But How?
description: What we’re losing is bigger than just an admissions policy.
content: What we’re losing is bigger than just an admissions policy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Hanover, N.J.
description: With good schools and relatively low property taxes, this Morris County community is popular with buyers. No surprise, then, that the market is tight.
content: With good schools and relatively low property taxes, this Morris County community is popular with buyers. No surprise, then, that the market is tight.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Stoneleigh, a Native Approach to Formal Landscaping
description: If you can create a native garden that looks at home on the grounds of a historic Philadelphia Main Line estate, you can do it anywhere.
content: If you can create a native garden that looks at home on the grounds of a historic Philadelphia Main Line estate, you can do it anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. ‘Fully’ Supports Sweden’s Bid to Join NATO, Biden Says
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has blocked Sweden’s NATO membership bid.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has blocked Sweden’s NATO membership bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Large Explosion in Russian-Occupied Makiivka
description: A video posted on Telegram and geolocated by The New York Times shows an explosion in Makiivka.
content: A video posted on Telegram and geolocated by The New York Times shows an explosion in Makiivka.
source.name: The New York Times
